title: AB 2687
content: The people of California enact the following. Section 23152 of the Vehicle Code in California prohibits driving under the influence of alcohol. It is illegal to drive with a blood alcohol concentration of 0.08% or higher. The BAC limit is based on grams of alcohol per 100 milliliters of blood or grams of alcohol per 210 liters of breath. If a chemical test is performed within three hours of driving and shows a BAC of 0.08% or higher, it is presumed that the person was over the limit while driving. In a prosecution, there is a presumption that a person had 0.08% or more alcohol in their blood while driving if a chemical test within three hours shows the same. It is illegal for a drug addict to drive, except if in an approved treatment program. It is illegal for a person addicted to drugs to drive, except if in an approved treatment program. It is also unlawful to drive a commercial vehicle with 0.04% or more alcohol in the blood. Starting July 1, 2018, it is illegal to drive with 0.04% or more alcohol in the blood when a passenger for hire is in the vehicle. A passenger for hire is someone who pays or is expected to pay for the ride. It is also unlawful to drive under the influence of any drug. It is illegal to drive under the influence of any drug or with a blood alcohol level of 0.08% or more, which causes bodily injury to another person. It is unlawful to drive with a blood alcohol level of 0.08% or more, causing bodily injury to another person. In a prosecution, it is presumed that the person had 0.08% or more alcohol in their blood at the time of driving if a chemical test within three hours after driving confirms it. Neglecting any duty imposed by law while driving does not require proof of violating a specific code section. In a prosecution for driving a commercial vehicle with 0.04% or more alcohol in the blood, it is not necessary to prove a specific code violation. If a chemical test within three hours after driving shows 0.04% or more alcohol, it is presumed that the person had that level at the time of driving. Neglecting any duty imposed by law while driving can lead to charges. It is illegal to drive a motor vehicle with 0.04% or more alcohol in the blood if a passenger for hire is in the vehicle and causes bodily injury to another person. Passenger for hire refers to someone who pays or is expected to pay for the ride. If a person is found to have 0.04% or more alcohol in their blood while driving, it is presumed they had that level at the time of driving. In a prosecution, it is presumed that a person had 0.04% or more alcohol in their blood at the time of driving if they had that level within three hours after driving. It is illegal to drive under the influence of any drug or a combination of alcohol and drugs, leading to bodily injury to another person. It is unlawful to drive under the combined influence of alcohol and drugs, causing bodily injury to another person. No reimbursement is required for local agencies or school districts due to changes in penalties for this offense.
